tasks.task: Implementing an Integrated Pest Management (IPM) approach using trap crops to control insect pests in vegetable production.
subtasks: Understanding the three methods of IPM: system-based practices, mechanical practices, and insecticides.
Recognizing the principle of host preference in selecting trap crops that pests prefer over the main crop.
Monitoring and scouting the trap crop for target pests to determine when to apply insecticides.
Evaluating the success of trap crops based on the reduction of pests in the main crop.
Applying insecticides to trap crops during peak insect activity to manage pest populations.
Adapting trap crop designs (perimeter or strip interplanting) based on farm size and the known pest source.
Utilizing trap crops to reduce insecticide use and protect natural enemies.
Considering additional benefits such as increased biodiversity, weed control, and wind reduction.

tasks.task: Demonstrating the effectiveness of trap crops through specific examples and case studies.
subtasks: Examining how sorghum serves as a trap crop for leaf-footed bugs in tomatoes, showing a 78% reduction in pests.
Observing the impact of trap crops on the main crop, such as preventing leaf-footed bug damage in tomatoes.
Highlighting creative uses of trap crops for marketing and additional benefits, like weed control and wind reduction.

tasks.task: Overcoming limitations and challenges in trap crop systems through experience and expert consultation.
subtasks: Addressing potential limitations of trap crop systems.
Seeking guidance from regional extension agents in designing an effective trap crop system for individual farms.
